sentence: Shares of The Home Depot ( HD ) are trading slightly up on the day to $38.13 as the company is expected to report its third quarter results tomorrow ahead of the opening bell.
The third quarter conference call is scheduled for the same day at 9:00 am EST; Dial-In: 913-312-6647, Password: 3986124.
The Wall Street consensus has The Home Depot reporting earnings of $0.58 per share for the quarter on $17.11 billion in sales.
For the full year 2011, the consensus estimates $2.35 per share in earnings on $69.66 billion in total sales.
For the third quarter 2010, the company reported earnings of $0.51 per share on $16.6 billion in total sales.
Analysts rate shares of Home Depot with 17 Buy rating, 11 Hold rating, and 0 Sell rating.
The average price target on shares of HD is $40 with a range from $33 to $44.
JPMorgan analysts highlight that severe weather conditions and events will likely result is better earnings for the quarter.
The firm also notes HD will continue to benefit from management's new labor scheduling system and supply chain initiatives, which will ultimately result in lower expenses.
For the quarter, the firm forecasts same store sales will increase 3 percent and that gross margin will grow by 20 basis points to 34.5 percent.
Earnings for the quarter are expected to be $0.59 per share on $17.1 billion in sales.
Operating expenses are expected to total 22.9 percent of sales, down 20 basis points year over year.
An analyst at JPMorgan comments, "We continue to believe that HD remains the best large cap investment in our universe.

In addition to these considerations, in the near term, we believe positive results in Q3, combined with the high 'sleep at night' factor given low exposure to the Holidays, and very easy weather comparisons in the peak Spring selling season position HD for share outperformance."
The firm has an Overweight rating and $42 price target on shares of HD leading up to the announcement of its third quarter results.

Analysts at Goldman Sachs indicate that their earnings estimate of $0.59 per share could prove to be conservative if same store sales are up roughly 3 to 3.5 percent, versys the firm's current forecast of a 2.4 percent growth.
Goldman believes sector sales momentum will be consistent with last quarters and that vendor sales trends will show signs of a slight recovery.

An analyst at Goldman comments, "We expect the same-store sales gap between HD and Lowe's ( LOW ) to stabilize, as LOW has, in our view, come to terms with the reality of its underperformance, and is starting to take remedial steps that could prove helpful to sales trends, if not to margins and profitability.
On the outlook, color on Q4 sales guidance will be in focus, given a challenging year-ago compare."
The firm currently has $40 price target and Neutral rating on shares of HD ahead of earnings.
Deutsche Bank's estimates are inline with other analysts as they forecast earnings of $0.59 per share for the quarter on a 3 percent gain in same store sales.
Looking ahead to Q4, the firm estimates comps will remain stable but said earnings will decline to $0.41 per share as Q4 is typically seasonally weaker.
An analyst at Deutsche comments, "Downside risks come primarily as housing markets may fail to improve, even as mortgage rates decline.
This would continue to weigh against HD's comps and constrain margin improvement outside of expense controls and other internal initiatives.
To the upside, HD has invested heavily in its distribution facilities and store labor, which may bear returns faster than we anticipate."
The firm has a Hold rating on shares of HD and picked shares of LOW as one of its top picks.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
